threats.title: Staff Credentials Stolen
threats.description: Staff credentials can be stolen via methods including brute force attacks, man in the middle attacks, them writing their details on a sticky note on their monitor, etc
threats.mitigation: Require two factor authentication and passwords that contain at least 10 characters, including at least one of each of upper case letter, lower case letter, number, and special character. Provide training to staff on best practices for password security.

threats.title: Staff Session Hijacked
threats.description: Staff session tokens get stolen by a threat actor and used maliciously to use the application as the staff member.
threats.mitigation: Use secure cookies with a session token sufficient length and entropy (128 bits long and at 64 bits of entropy). Also provide staff with training on avoiding phishing attacks and use email filters.

threats.title: Spoofed Account Performing Malicious Actions
threats.description: Accounts that have been spoofed can perform malicious acts without being able to prove whether the account was stolen by a threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Log all actions taken by actors, including login attempts with the actor's ip address, to ensure that the source of actions can be traced back to the actor that initiated them.

data.name: Authentication Token
data.description: Auth token with a 1 week timeout

data.name: Username
data.description: Request the hashed password for the given username

data.name: Authentication Response
data.description: Either an authentication token with a 1 week timeout (if login successful), or a message saying login details were incorrect, but not specifying why (if not)

threats.title: Disclosure of Used Usernames
threats.description: When the actor supplies an incorrect or invalid username or password, they can determine whether the username is used in the system because the feedback specifies which field is invalid.
threats.mitigation: Only provide generic feedback stating that the username or password is incorrect.

threats.title: Network Tampering (Adversary in the Middle Attack)
threats.description: Threat actor intercepts network traffic with the staff member's user details
threats.mitigation: Mitigated - Encrypt all network communication and use transport layer security

threats.title: Denial of Service From Repeated Login Attempts
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly attempts to login to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff logins behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the system, modify the intended action, then forward it to the system.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the system, steal the authentication token, then discard the packet so the logout request is not completed. The threat actor then has a authentication token for a staff member.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Data Tampering
threats.description: An actor gains access to the authentication store and alters or removes entries
threats.mitigation: Store database credentials in a secure location and not in plain text. Store user credentials in an encrypted form. Again use the least privileged principle. Also only allow read access to the database from the login endpoint.

threats.title: Visibility of Restricted Data
threats.description: Staff members should not be able to see information about other actors credentials.
threats.mitigation: Apply the least privileged principle to ensure the minimum amount data is visible.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Stealing Credentials with Fake Login Page
threats.description: A threat actor creates a fake login page resembling the real login page. This is then used to trick staff members into sharing their login details with the threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Purchase similar domain names so that threat actors can't use them. Use a simple domain name so it's easier for the users to identify.

threats.title: Disclosure of Used Usernames
threats.description: When the actor supplies an incorrect or invalid username or password, they can determine whether the username is used in the system because the feedback specifies which field is invalid.
threats.mitigation: Only provide generic feedback stating that the username or password is incorrect.

threats.title: Repeated Login Attempts
threats.description: Repeated login attempts by an actor use significant resources such as CPU and memory
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Distributed Denial of Service Attack
threats.description: Similarly to the repeated login attempts, a distributed denial of service attack can cause significant CPU and memory usage. It can be hard to mitigate because requests come from lots of different sources, so can't all be blocked.
threats.mitigation:
Use an access control list and scale up server capacity to allow for more concurrent requests. It is assumed that this is managed by the cloud service provider.

Additionally, you could put staff logins behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: SQL Injection
threats.description: When user inputs are not sanitised and handled correctly by the process, it can lead to malicious actions being performed within the process, leading the threat actor performing actions they don't have the privileges to do.
threats.mitigation: Sanitise user input so that it can't be executed as code.

threats.title: Session Hijacking
threats.description: Staff session tokens get stolen by a threat actor and used maliciously to use the application as the staff member.
threats.mitigation: Use secure cookies with a session token sufficient length and entropy (128 bits long and at 64 bits of entropy). Also provide staff with training on avoiding phishing attacks and use email filters.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: Repeated request attempts by an actor use significant resources such as CPU and memory
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Performing Actions Above Privilege Level
threats.description: By failing to restrict administration actions, staff members could perform actions above their privilege level.
threats.mitigation: Implement role based authorisation for all system actions.

threats.title: Impersonation of a Council Staff Member
threats.description: A threat actor could impersonate a council staff member and send emails to applicants requesting additional information (if they have their contact information through another means).
threats.mitigation: Purchase similar email domains to ensure threat actors can't use them. Use a simple email domain to make it easier for applicants to detect fake emails.

threats.title: Session Hijacking
threats.description: Staff session tokens get stolen by a threat actor and used maliciously to use the application as the staff member.
threats.mitigation: Use secure cookies with a session token sufficient length and entropy (128 bits long and at 64 bits of entropy). Also provide staff with training on avoiding phishing attacks and use email filters.

threats.title: Staff Credentials Stolen
threats.description: Staff credentials can be stolen via methods including brute force attacks, man in the middle attacks, them writing their details on a sticky note on their monitor, etc
threats.mitigation: Require two factor authentication and passwords that contain at least 10 characters, including at least one of each of upper case letter, lower case letter, number, and special character. Provide training to staff on best practices for password security.

threats.title: Spoofed Account/Email Performing Malicious Actions
threats.description: Accounts that have been spoofed can perform malicious acts without being able to prove whether the account was stolen by a threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Log all actions taken by actors, including login attempts with the actor's ip address, to ensure that the source of actions can be traced back to the actor that initiated them.

threats.title: Stealing Details with Fake Application Page
threats.description: A threat actor creates a fake application page resembling the real application page. This is then used to trick applicants into sharing their details with the threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Purchase similar domain names so that threat actors can't use them. Use a simple domain name so it's easier for the users to identify.

threats.title: Repeated Applications
threats.description: Repeated applications by an actor use significant resources such as CPU and memory
threats.mitigation: Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

threats.title: Distributed Denial of Service Attack
threats.description: Similarly to the repeated login attempts, a distributed denial of service attack can cause significant CPU and memory usage. It can be hard to mitigate because requests come from lots of different sources, so can't all be blocked.
threats.mitigation: Use an access control list and scale up server capacity to allow for more concurrent requests. It is assumed that this is managed by the cloud service provider.

threats.title: SQL/Code Injection
threats.description: When user inputs are not sanitised and handled correctly by the process, it can lead to malicious actions being performed within the process, leading the threat actor performing actions they don't have the privileges to do.
threats.mitigation: Sanitise user input so that it can't be executed as code.

threats.title: Fake Applications
threats.description: A threat actor could create fake applications to waste the council's time, then deny it.
threats.mitigation: Log all actions taken by actors with the actor's ip address, to ensure that the source of actions can be traced back to the actor that initiated them.

threats.title: Stealing Details with Fake Page
threats.description: A threat actor creates a fake page resembling the real page. This is then used to trick applicants into sharing their application ID with the threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Purchase similar domain names so that threat actors can't use them. Use a simple domain name so it's easier for the users to identify.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: Repeated requests by an actor use significant resources such as CPU and memory
threats.mitigation: Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

threats.title: Distributed Denial of Service Attack
threats.description: Similarly to the repeated login attempts, a distributed denial of service attack can cause significant CPU and memory usage. It can be hard to mitigate because requests come from lots of different sources, so can't all be blocked.
threats.mitigation: Use an access control list and scale up server capacity to allow for more concurrent requests. It is assumed that this is managed by the cloud service provider.

threats.title: SQL/Code Injection
threats.description: When user inputs are not sanitised and handled correctly by the process, it can lead to malicious actions being performed within the process, leading the threat actor performing actions they don't have the privileges to do.
threats.mitigation: Sanitise user input so that it can't be executed as code.

threats.title: Database Filling Up
threats.description: If the system receives significantly more applications than expected, the database could run out of space to store information about new applications.
threats.mitigation: Partially mitigate by enabling storage notifications to system administrators so that they can increase the size of the database.

data.name: Application status information
data.description:
Status
Staff member responsible
Supporting documents (optional)

data.name: Application details
data.description: All application details plus the 8-digit application identifier

data.name: Application details
data.description:
For each property owner:
- pronoun
- first name
- last name
- email
- phone number

Details of the property (just its address)
And supporting documents

threats.title: Repeated Applications
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends applications to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
As a simple mitigation, limit the number of applications from a single phone number or email address in a certain time frame.

Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the system, modify the data, then forward it to the system. They could also intercept the applicant's personal information and supporting documents, and use them for their personal gain.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the user, gaining access to the supporting documents
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the user, gaining access to their application information
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

data.name: Application ID
data.description: Also maybe a supporting documentation flag?

threats.title: Brute Force Attack
threats.description: Given the application ID is only 8 characters, a threat actor could obtain it via brute force methods. This could lead to supporting documents being accessible to the threat actor.
threats.mitigation: Rate limiting and logging could partially mitigate this threat. It could be further reduced by using a longer application ID, such as 16 characters, or preferably, implementing a login system for applications.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor intercepts the application ID submitted to the application.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation: Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

data.name: Decision email
data.description:
Email with decision number and a letter of confirmation/denial.
Sent to all relevant applicants

data.name: Application information
data.description: Summary of application and the extra information to be provided

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept emails meant for the user, gaining access to information about their application
threats.mitigation: Use an email provider with encryption and that can only be accessed through HTTPS

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept emails from the applicant to the council. This would allow them to gain access to the additional documentation about the application the applicant is sending.
threats.mitigation: Use an email provider with encryption and that can only be accessed through HTTPS

threats.title: Repeated Emails
threats.description: A threat actor could send repeated emails to the council system, overwhelming the server.
threats.mitigation: It is assumed that this is handled by the email server.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the system, modify the intended action, then forward it to the system.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the system, modify the intended action or steal data, then forward it to the system.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

threats.title: Repeated Requests
threats.description: A malicious actor repeatedly sends requests to the system, slowing down access for other actors
threats.mitigation:
Put a limit on the number of requests allowed from a single IP address within a certain time frame. Blacklist users who repeatedly exceed this limit.

Additionally, you could put staff pages behind a firewall and only allow access from the local council network or through a secure VPN. However, this is not feasible in the current system as there is a requirement for the website to be publicly available.

threats.title: New STRIDE threat
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat
threats.mitigation: Provide remediation for this threat or a reason if status is N/A

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept packets meant for the staff member.
threats.mitigation: Require HTTPS and transport layer security.

data.name: Confirmation email
data.description:
Email with 8-digit application code 
confirming application.
Also includes summary of the application.

threats.title: Adversary in the Middle Attack
threats.description: A threat actor can intercept emails meant for the user, gaining access to their application ID, and therefore their supporting documents.
threats.mitigation: Use an email provider with encryption and that can only be accessed through HTTPS

threats.title: Database Filling Up
threats.description: If too many users are registered, issues could occur due to the database filling up
threats.mitigation: This is mitigated by only allowing users to be created by administrators. Checks are performed before adding a new user account to ensure the database has enough space.
